shortIntro.title: What Your Device Needs for Smooth Clash of Clans Gameplay
shortIntro.para1: Clash of Clans is one of the most optimized strategy games on mobile. It runs smoothly on most modern Android and iOS devices, but players still need a stable device to avoid slow loading, lag during attacks, and animation delays.
shortIntro.para2: Even though COC is not a heavy FPS title, having a slightly better chipset, faster storage, and updated OS helps in keeping gameplay responsive during Clan War attacks, Legends League pushes, and high-troop-count battles.

intro: Below are the updated minimum and recommended specifications required to run Clash of Clans smoothly on Android and iOS devices. These details are based on official requirements and community-tested benchmarks.

minimum.GPU: Basic GPU support (Adreno 306 / Mali-400 or equivalent)
minimum.Internet: Stable 2–5 Mbps connection to avoid attack disconnections

recommended.Internet: Low-ping 4G/5G or Wi-Fi for stable Multiplayer & Clan War attacks

ios_intro: iOS devices are generally more optimized for COC. Here are the minimum and recommended requirements for smooth performance.
fps_intro: Clash of Clans does not rely on high FPS, but smoother animations and faster UI responses occur on devices with better CPUs and higher refresh rate screens.
settings_intro: To ensure smooth village navigating and lag-free war attacks, below are the ideal device settings for low-end and high-end devices.

faqIntroText: Here are the most frequently asked questions related to Clash of Clans performance, device support, and stability.

faqList.question: Can COC run smoothly on low-end devices?
faqList.answer: Yes, COC is optimized for older phones, but loading and troop animations may feel slower.

faqList.question: Does Clash of Clans support high FPS or 120Hz screens?
faqList.answer: The game runs at a capped internal FPS, but high refresh rate displays improve UI smoothness.

faqList.question: Is fast internet required?
faqList.answer: A stable low-latency connection is more important than high speed. Even 3–5 Mbps is enough.
